member.name: T:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEEventCmdlet
member.summary: Records user interaction event data. For more information see Recording Events.

para.para: A list of event data from the session.

The session ID associated with the user's visit. Your application generates the sessionId when a user first visits your website or uses your application. Amazon Personalize uses the sessionId to associate events with the user before they log in. For more information, see Recording Events.
The tracking ID for the event. The ID is generated by a call to the CreateEventTracker API.
The user associated with the event.

member.name: P:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEEventCmdlet.Select
member.summary: Use the -Select parameter to control the cmdlet output. The cmdlet doesn't have a return value by default. Specifying -Select '*' will result in the cmdlet returning the whole service response (Amazon.PersonalizeEvents.Model.PutEventsResponse). Specifying -Select '^ParameterName' will result in the cmdlet returning the selected cmdlet parameter value.

member.name: P:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEEventCmdlet.PassThru
member.summary: Changes the cmdlet behavior to return the value passed to the SessionId parameter. The -PassThru parameter is deprecated, use -Select '^SessionId' instead. This parameter will be removed in a future version.

member.name: P:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEEventCmdlet.Force
member.summary: This parameter overrides confirmation prompts to force the cmdlet to continue its operation. This parameter should always be used with caution.

member.name: T:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEItemCmdlet
member.summary: Adds one or more items to an Items dataset. For more information see Importing Items Incrementally.

para.para: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Items dataset you are adding the item or items to.

member.name: P:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEItemCmdlet.Select
member.summary: Use the -Select parameter to control the cmdlet output. The cmdlet doesn't have a return value by default. Specifying -Select '*' will result in the cmdlet returning the whole service response (Amazon.PersonalizeEvents.Model.PutItemsResponse). Specifying -Select '^ParameterName' will result in the cmdlet returning the selected cmdlet parameter value.

member.name: P:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEItemCmdlet.PassThru
member.summary: Changes the cmdlet behavior to return the value passed to the DatasetArn parameter. The -PassThru parameter is deprecated, use -Select '^DatasetArn' instead. This parameter will be removed in a future version.

member.name: P:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEItemCmdlet.Force
member.summary: This parameter overrides confirmation prompts to force the cmdlet to continue its operation. This parameter should always be used with caution.

member.name: T:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEUserCmdlet
member.summary: Adds one or more users to a Users dataset. For more information see Importing Users Incrementally.

para.para: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Users dataset you are adding the user or users to.

member.name: P:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEUserCmdlet.Select
member.summary: Use the -Select parameter to control the cmdlet output. The cmdlet doesn't have a return value by default. Specifying -Select '*' will result in the cmdlet returning the whole service response (Amazon.PersonalizeEvents.Model.PutUsersResponse). Specifying -Select '^ParameterName' will result in the cmdlet returning the selected cmdlet parameter value.

member.name: P:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEUserCmdlet.PassThru
member.summary: Changes the cmdlet behavior to return the value passed to the DatasetArn parameter. The -PassThru parameter is deprecated, use -Select '^DatasetArn' instead. This parameter will be removed in a future version.

member.name: P:Amazon.PowerShell.Cmdlets.PERSE.WritePERSEUserCmdlet.Force
member.summary: This parameter overrides confirmation prompts to force the cmdlet to continue its operation. This parameter should always be used with caution.
